today maybe this application is running in an on-prem vm environment or is and you are
having to spend some amount in managing and patching this application okay and then the last reason don't
underestimate this reason i've talked to many many companies in the last two or three years
they are evacuating their data center because they're moving to the cloud they're taking some of the applications
maybe developing them in a cloud native manner but then also take the line of business
applications which they don't want to run anymore and they want to simply evacuate okay so one more concept
slide here which is how do you typically take your applications and migrate
to a public cloud provider right and gartner calls it a 5r model and i've only shown
you four hours here so one is lift and shift you take your vm and you migrate that vm over to the
cloud of course that works we know that works but that does not allow you to take advantage of the capabilities that cloud
may offer the other r is the refactor where you can take that application and
maybe start taking advantage of some pass capabilities maybe run it inside app service right you leave other pieces
the way they are take the web piece run inside an app service or maybe take your database
piece and see if it can be run in a database as a service capability azure sql database or or mysql or something like
that right and then of course you have the other r which is the reimagine which is you're trying to build this
application natively as a micro services based application using you know from the ground up or maybe in
a server-less manner using event-driven functions and things like that and then of course
there's this option of replacing your application maybe you don't even need this application to be a custom application
and you want it to be some sort of a sas application with some low code development model and and if you're wondering what the
fifth r is it is of course retiring applications doing a portfolio analysis
and seeing that there are some applications that you absolutely don't need okay that's the entire piece what i'm here to
talk about is another r here which i call the lift and reshape which is becoming
important in my mind since the windows containers have become available okay
so let's compare the approaches so in rehost keep in mind that we are not changing
the code at all so the code changes are none but our operational costs are still high because you know you're running the vms

the cost costs are high because even though you are paying for the entire vm your vm
utilization typically that we find is about 10 11 okay so that's rehost refactor

is the re-platform where the code changes are low the operational costs
can be reduced and mainly because you're taking your existing application the windows application
you're containerizing it and the operational costs are low because you're not in the business of applying patches
necessarily that's one way of reducing the operational cost and the other way of reducing the operational cost is when you're running
on top of an orchestrator like kubernetes you have capabilities like health checking available to you
so if if the container is unhealthy you want to add another instance of the
cod or a container kubernetes can do those things for you automatically it can also apply some memory
constraints and say only this much memory is allowed or this much cpu is allowed
so you have some some way to manage that in that manner the other reason the cost is low is
because you're doing a higher density deployment so you can have one vm but you can host
multiple applications because now you have the ability of not just isolation but also the ability to apply quotas on

okay first foremost i think this should be familiar to everybody so you have this notion of an image
which is an immutable copy of your application so you take your application binaries
you take your dependencies you create an immutable copy of that and that's what a container image is and then
then you run this image on some sort of a container host and typically you store these container
images in some sort of a repository it could be a microsoft container repository it could be an enterprise
repository that you have now your image is broken up into layers and this is an important concept
to understand that at the bottom most layer is the layer where you have the operating system mapping so it
could be a base container image server core or nano server and i'll explain
the the differences between nano and core in a moment and then on top of that you might have some other layers
and on top of that you might have your application layer this is an important concept to understand because these layers
get cached and only the layer that is changing gets deployed so this is an important concept to understand here as
well okay so when we talk about windows containers there are three types of containers now
keep in mind that you know linux for example always had the notion of containers
because linux was based on this idea that you know the kernel is really small and and then the notion of of name
spaces and change groups has existed for a decade or more in the linux side on the windows side the operating system
shipped with not just the kernel but all of the you know in 32 and 634 dlls
so so the notion of containers was not there until windows server 2016 came along and
microsoft created this notion of containers okay so because of the differences in how linux and windows
operating system is based there are differences in images here and when i when we do a demo we'll
get into a little bit more but it will suffice to understand that there are three type of container
images so you have a nano server image which is about 100 megs in size and typically used for net core applications then you
have server core image which can give you a full.net framework support
about 1.5 gigs and they've brought it down some so closer to a gig and then of course you
have the windows server image which gives you a full fidelity experience okay this came out with
windows server 2019 okay all the images can be run in a process isolation mode
and hyper-v isolation what do i mean by that so you can either run it run the container
as a process so one container is one process another container is one
process or you have the ability to take each container and run it in a hyper-v isolation mode
so if you're trying to run if you want a high level of security then you typically want to run it in a
hyper-v isolation mode okay and i have to point out that right now
in kubernetes aks the hyper-v isolation is not supported only the process isolation is supported
